description: From Middle English innermost, innermest, in-nermast, alteration (due to Middle English inner, innere (“inner”)) of Old English innemest (“innermost”), equivalent to inner +‎ -most.

entries.meaning: Farthest inside or towards the center or middle.
examples: She poured her innermost feelings into her journal.

entries.meaning: That which is innermost; the core.
examples: […]  he had decided to not seek outside of himself where companionship and friendliness might be a soothing submergence. It seemed he had instead chosen to turn deeply inwards, towards the measures and pains of his wracked innermosts.
